items.title: Don't strip filename from errors
items.body:
These lines strip the file name from the reported errors.
https://github.com/dbader/pytest-mypy/blob/8c99601158157ad96698d5a89357035e701bcf90/src/pytest_mypy.py#L234-L237

While this results in a cleaner looking output, it means the output is less useful when using pytest-mypy with other tools like Pycharm. When I change the code to include the filename, Pycharm turns it into a link which I can click to bring me directly to the place where the error is. Without the filename this doesn't work.

items.title: Cannot install using poetry due to python version constraint
items.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to add `pytest-mypy` to an existing project that manages its dependencies using Poetry. The project is using Python 3.8, so I would expect `pytest-mypy` to be compatible (based on the classifiers in `setup.py`), but install fails with:

```
[SolverProblemError]
The current project's Python requirement (>=3.8) is not compatible with some of the required packages Python requirement:
  - pytest-mypy requires Python ~=3.4

Because pytest-mypy (0.6.2) requires Python ~=3.4
 and no versions of pytest-mypy match >0.6.2,<0.7.0, pytest-mypy is forbidden.
```

I think this is caused by the `python_requires` specification in `setup.py` - Poetry interprets `~=3.4` to mean that the package is compatible with python `>=3.4.0, <3.5.0`. Should this be `>=3.4` instead?

items.title: Deprecation warning from pytest
items.body:
Hi, thank you for your great package.

 I saw this warning while running `pytest --mypy`.
```
/home/reza/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest_mypy.py:82: 22 tests with warnings
  /home/reza/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest_mypy.py:82: PytestDeprecationWarning: direct construction of MypyFileItem has been deprecated, please use MypyFileItem.from_parent
    item = MypyFileItem(path, parent)

/home/reza/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest_mypy.py:87: 22 tests with warnings
  /home/reza/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest_mypy.py:87: PytestDeprecationWarning: direct construction of MypyFileItem has been deprecated, please use MypyFileItem.from_parent
    nodeid='::'.join([item.nodeid, nodeid_name]),

/home/reza/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest_mypy.py:108
  /home/reza/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pytest_mypy.py:108: PytestDeprecationWarning: direct construction of MypyStatusItem has been deprecated, please use MypyStatusItem.from_parent
    items.append(MypyStatusItem(nodeid_name, session, config, session))
```
It seems that this deprecation warning is added in pytest from version 5.4.0.
I received this warning with both of these configurations.
* Python 3.6.9, pytest-5.4.1
* Python 3.8.2, pytest-5.4.1

items.title: Clarify which pytest items are MyPy when running with --verbose flag.
items.body:
When running with the `--verbose` flag, pytest-flake8 [handily annotates each output line](https://github.com/tholo/pytest-flake8/blob/c485d5e85ac6b2138405378e9763e7025f58b023/pytest_flake8.py#L90) to clarify that it ran that test (i.e. it's not a hand-written test). For example:

```sh
pytest --verbose
```
```
============================= test session starts ==============================
platform linux -- Python 3.8.1, pytest-5.3.5, py-1.8.1, pluggy-0.13.1 -- /usr/local/bin/python
cachedir: .pytest_cache
rootdir: /usr/src/app, inifile: setup.cfg
plugins: flake8-1.0.4, mypy-0.4.2, cov-2.8.1
collecting ... collected 33 items / 2 deselected / 31 selected

Running mypy on 11 files... done with status 0
Success: no issues found in 11 source files

mymodule/__init__::py PASSED                                              [  x%]
mymodule/__init__.py::FLAKE8 PASSED                                       [  x%] <
mymodule/__main__::py PASSED                                              [  x%]
mymodule/__main__.py::FLAKE8 PASSED                                       [ x%] <
…
mymodule/utils.py::module.utils.function_name PASSED      [ x%]
…
mymodule/tests/test_function.py::test_function PASSED [ x%]
…
```

Would it be possible to similarly alter the [`MyPyItem`](https://github.com/dbader/pytest-mypy/blob/e1e4ebd49da513126afd594c96b22c0d321b9369/src/pytest_mypy.py#L84) to similarly mark type-checks as separate from hand-written tests in pytest's verbose output?

items.title: Consider supporting pytest-xdist
items.body:
It seems that the mypy errors are ignored when run with `pytest-xdist`’s `-n` option.

Could you support `pytest-xdist`?

items.title: pytest-mypy only checks test files when providing testpaths
items.body:
With a src layout for files, and this setup.cfg:
```
[options]
package_dir=
  = src
packages = find:
setup_requires =
  pytest-runner

[options.packages.find]
where = src/
exclude =
    test
[tool:pytest]
python_files = *.py
# providing testpaths makes pytest-mypy only check tests
testpaths = test
addopts =
  --mypy
[mypy]
# this line sadly gets ignored using pytest-mypy
files = src
```

mypy is only applied to the files in test folder (fails on imports from src folder). This might even be following the spec of mypy (which says setup.cfg "files" will only be used if no other argument is provided), but it makes pytest-pylint less useful.

items.title: mypy errors do not fail pytest build when using ignore_missing_imports = true
items.body:
When `mypy` fails with an error, `pytest --mypy` still succeeds, when setup.cfg contains `ignore_missing_imports = true`. Should fail.

When setup.cfg does not contain `ignore_missing_imports = true`, process fails for me (as it should).

```
$ py.test --mypy -m mypy 
=================================================================== test session starts ===================================================================
platform darwin -- Python 3.7.3, pytest-5.3.1, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.13.1
rootdir: /Users/tkruse/work/myapp, inifile: setup.cfg, testpaths: test
plugins: pylint-0.14.1, mypy-0.4.2, cov-2.8.1
Running mypy on 6 files... done with status 1
...
error: Argument 1... has incompatible type "str"; expected "List[str]"
...
Found 2 errors in 1 file (checked 6 source files)
=========== 6 passed, 20 deselected, 4 warnings in 1.31s

$ echo $?
0
```

mypy output:
```
$ mypy myapp --ignore-missing-imports
...
Found 2 errors in 1 file (checked 13 source files)

$ echo $?
1
```

items.title: Running mypy only on certain files
items.body:
I have a large codebase and I would like to run mypy only on a subset of it.

I have the globs to check defined in the `files` setting in my mypy.ini file, but since the pytest-mypy plugin explicitly passes a list of all of the files, that behavior is overridden.

What do you think of adding a command line argument which turns off the behavior of passing the filenames to mypy, or lets me override it, or something to that effect?

items.body:
https://github.com/dbader/pytest-mypy/blob/f19d8ec9e6232d05fd34a816c8a9f3b67efdfa7a/tox.ini#L22
This was technically a separate occurrence of the same issue (for which there is a separate issue upstream: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/3223

items.body:
```
$ venv/bin/pytest --mypy tests
=========================================================== test session starts ===========================================================
platform darwin -- Python 3.7.3, pytest-5.0.1, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.13.0

            [-m MODULE] [-p PACKAGE] [-c PROGRAM_TEXT] [files ...]
mypy: error: unrecognized arguments: --foo
done with status 2
```
I don't see how this should be possible (stderr dumping _before_ the "done with status" message):
https://github.com/dbader/pytest-mypy/blob/6671f41f99bd1a614851db0953f913c28c506183/src/pytest_mypy.py#L56-L65

items.title: pytest-mypy < 0.4.0 emits false positive with new mypys
items.body:
This is likely a `wontfix`, but old versions of the plugin call any output an error. Newer versions of mypy (0.730 at least) produce output on success which causes a false positive:
```
=========================== FAILURES ============================
__________________________ mypy cli.py __________________________
Success: no issues found in 1 source file
```
The solution is to upgrade to `pytest-mypy >= 0.4.0` or downgrade `mypy`.

items.title: Release to PyPi for 4.0
items.body:
Just wondering when releasing 4.0 to PyPi is anticipated to happen; and if there's anything blocking the release from being made?

Happy to help with anything blocking to help get the release out a little sooner.

items.title: TravisCI times out
items.body:
In the course of adding py3.8 support in PR #44 the author also added `mypy==0.720` which tipped the testing matrix for `py36` over the 50 minute time limit.

This issue proposes changing the `.travis.yml` to partition the testing matrix.

How that should happen... is open discussion. 

Over at `vcrpy` they use the following:
```yml
env:
    matrix:
        - TOX_SUFFIX="flakes"
        - TOX_SUFFIX="requests"
        - TOX_SUFFIX="httplib2"
        - TOX_SUFFIX="boto3"
        - TOX_SUFFIX="urllib3"
        - TOX_SUFFIX="tornado4"
        - TOX_SUFFIX="aiohttp"
script:
- tox -e "${TOX_SUFFIX}"
```
https://github.com/kevin1024/vcrpy/blob/master/.travis.yml

So we could partition by pytest versions or mypy versions.

There will have to be some careful interplay between the `.travis.yml` and `tox.ini`

```
========================================================= warnings summary ==========================================================
venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/_pytest/mark/structures.py:324
  venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/_pytest/mark/structures.py:324: PytestUnknownMarkWarning: Unknown pytest.mark.mypy - is this a typo?  You can register custom marks to avoid this warning - for details, see https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/mark.html
    PytestUnknownMarkWarning,

-- Docs: https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/warnings.html
```

I guess this is related to what was done in #18?

items.title: Make a conda package
items.body: As title. Would be very useful. :-)

items.title: -m option is included in the pytest command which is conflicted with only  perform mypy checks option
items.body: -m option is not available.

items.title: Still slow
items.body:
Even with the change to invoke with --incremental, this plugin is still really slow:

```
time mypy net_devices2

real    0m3.822s
user    0m3.724s
sys     0m0.092s

```
```
time pytest --mypy net_devices2

real    2m54.786s
user    2m52.424s
sys     0m1.944s
```

mypy==0.620
pytest==3.4.1
pytest-cov==2.5.1
pytest-forked==0.2
pytest-mypy==0.3.2
pytest-xdist==1.22.5

items.title: Allow passing of --check-untyped-defs
items.body: It would be nice if I could pass this option to mypy through your plugin

items.title: Publish master to PyPI
items.body:
Hi, @dbader, thanks for the great plugin!

I wonder if it would be possible to publish the master branch to PyPI, as [this statement](https://github.com/dbader/pytest-mypy/blob/809d68ab13c959a589c557ae6f6134cf6fb81043/pytest_mypy.py#L58) breaks on new versions of mypy (somewhere around v.0.580 I think). The [new function signature](https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/7519e89ae8054ea3f22c4d13f16aaf9ae8f10f0a/mypy/main.py#L127) of ``mypy.main::type_check_only()`` has changed, and it seems to have been fixed by [this commit](https://github.com/dbader/pytest-mypy/commit/1958f97c6bb4e2b86a1767433974f65e2da6b293).

Thanks in advance!

items.title: Missing heading
items.body:
`pytest`: `test_backlog_search` (test name):
```
__________________________________________ test_backlog_search __________________________________________

backlog_entry = ([Entry(title='test-4', priority=2, note=''), Entry(title='test-5', priority=100, note=''), Entry(title='test-3', prio...t-2', priority=0, note=''), Entry(title='test-1', priority=-100, note='')], Entry(title='test-2', priority=0, note=''))

    def test_backlog_search(backlog_entry):
        backlog, entry = backlog_entry
>       assert backlog == backlog.search(pattern=entry.title)
E       AssertionError: assert [Entry(title=...100, note='')] == [Entry(title='...y=0, note='')]
E         At index 0 diff: Entry(title='test-4', priority=2, note='') != Entry(title='test-2', priority=0, note='')
E         Left contains more items, first extra item: Entry(title='test-5', priority=100, note='')
E         Use -v to get the full diff

tests/test_backlog.py:74: AssertionError

```
`pytest-flake8`: `FLAKE8-check`:
```
_____________________________________________ FLAKE8-check ______________________________________________
/home/david/Projects/backlog/tests/test_backlog.py:1:1: D100 Missing docstring in public module
/home/david/Projects/backlog/tests/test_backlog.py:7:1: I100 Import statements are in the wrong order. 'from backlog import Backlog' should be before 'import pytest' and in a different group.
/home/david/Projects/backlog/tests/test_backlog.py:11:1: D400 First line should end with a period
...
```
`pytest-pylint`: `[pylint] tests/test_backlog.py` (file name):
```
____________________________________ [pylint] tests/test_backlog.py _____________________________________
W: 14, 0: TODO try Backlog([...]) (fixme)
W: 36, 0: TODO testdir! (fixme)
C:  1, 0: Missing module docstring (missing-docstring)
W: 14, 8: Redefining name 'entry' from outer scope (line 27) (redefined-outer-name)
C: 27, 0: Missing function docstring (missing-docstring)
C: 35, 0: Missing function docstring (missing-docstring)
C: 48, 0: Missing function docstring (missing-docstring)
C: 53, 0: Missing function docstring (missing-docstring)
...
```
`pytest-mypy` doesn't show anything:
```
___________________________________________________  ____________________________________________________
tests/test_cli.py:6: error: No library stub file for module 'pytest'
tests/test_cli.py:6: note: (Stub files are from https://github.com/python/typeshed)
tests/test_cli.py:8: error: Cannot find module named 'backlog'
tests/test_cli.py:8: note: (Perhaps setting MYPYPATH or using the "--ignore-missing-imports" flag would help)
...
```

items.title: required argument 'flush_errors' error with latest version of mypy
items.body:
Hi @dbader,

`pytest-mypy` seems to be broken with the latest release of `mypy==0.570`, but I did not yet have the time to investigate it further or fix it. It yields the following errors for each file:

```
[...]: in runtest
    res = mypy.main.type_check_only(sources, None, options)
E   TypeError: type_check_only() missing 1 required positional argument: 'flush_errors'
```

items.title: `mypy_path` option or `MYPYPATH` is not respected?
items.body:
I have mypy.ini and have 2 global falgs
```
[mypy]
ignore_missing_imports = yes
mypy_path = src
```

Certainly ignore_missing_imports flags works but mypy gets always run for tests directory.
I tried to set `export MYPYPATH=src` but no luck.

Looking at
```
def pytest_collect_file(path, parent):
    config = parent.config
    if config.option.mypy and path.ext == '.py':
        return MypyItem(path, parent)
```
It appears to me `path` is from `testpaths` under `pytest.ini`
So to solve my problem (to run mypy on src code), I've added src addition to tests dir as follows
```
[pytest]
testpaths =
    tests src
```
Is this expected behavior?

items.title: Slow
items.body:
It looks like a nice and useful plugin, but unfortunately is terribly slow:

```
$ time (mypy . ; pytest)
real    0m5.491s
user    0m4.944s
sys     0m0.304s

$ time (find . -name \*.py | xargs mypy ; pytest)
real    0m5.322s
user    0m4.752s
sys     0m0.292s

$ time pytest --mypy
real    0m44.829s
user    0m42.872s
sys     0m0.488s
```

items.title: --silent-imports flag?
items.body:
I normally have to pass the --silent-imports flag, to mypy to avoid all sort of errors.
This plugin at the moment doesn't let any extra flag to be passed to mypy though, is that correct?
